title: Schwartz-type integrals in a biharmonic plane

title_detail.value: Schwartz-type integrals in a biharmonic plane

summary:
We consider a two-dimensional commutative algebra B over the field of complex
numbers. The algebra B is associated with the biharmonic equation. For
monogenic functions with values in B, we consider a Schwartz-type boundary
value problem (associated with the main biharmonic problem) for a half-plane
and for a disk of the biharmonic plane. We obtain solutions in explicit forms
by means of Schwartz-type integrals and prove that the mentioned problem is
solvable unconditionally for a half-plane but it is solvable for a disk if and
only if a certain natural condition is satisfied.

summary_detail.value:
We consider a two-dimensional commutative algebra B over the field of complex
numbers. The algebra B is associated with the biharmonic equation. For
monogenic functions with values in B, we consider a Schwartz-type boundary
value problem (associated with the main biharmonic problem) for a half-plane
and for a disk of the biharmonic plane. We obtain solutions in explicit forms
by means of Schwartz-type integrals and prove that the mentioned problem is
solvable unconditionally for a half-plane but it is solvable for a disk if and
only if a certain natural condition is satisfied.

author: S. A. Plaksa
fulltext:
Schwartz-type integrals in a biharmonic plane
S.V. Gryshchuk, S.A. Plaksa

arXiv:1202.0993v1 [math.CV] 5 Feb 2012

Abstract
We consider the commutative algebra B over the field of complex numbers with the bases {e1 , e2 }
satisfying the conditions (e21 + e22 )2 = 0 , e21 + e22 6= 0 . The algebra B is associated with the biharmonic
equation. For monogenic functions with values in B , we consider a Schwartz-type boundary value problem
(associated with the main biharmonic problem) for a half-plane and for a disk of the biharmonic plane
{xe1 + ye2 } , where x, y are real. We obtain solutions in explicit forms by means of Schwartz-type integrals
and prove that the mentioned problem is solvable unconditionally for a half-plane but it is solvable for a
disk if and only if a certain natural condition is satisfied.

1

Introduction

We say that an associative commutative two-dimensional algebra B with the unit 1 over the field of complex
numbers C is biharmonic if in B there exists a biharmonic basis, i.e a bases {e1 , e2 } satisfying the conditions
(e21 + e22 )2 = 0,

e21 + e22 6= 0 .

(1)

V. F. Kovalev and I. P. Mel'nichenko [1] found a multiplication table for a biharmonic basis {e1 , e2 } :
e1 = 1,

e22 = e1 + 2ie2 ,

(2)

where i is the imaginary complex unit. In the paper [2] I. P. Mel'nichenko proved that there exists the unique
biharmonic algebra B with a non-biharmonic basis {1, ρ} for which
ρ = 2e1 + 2ie2

(3)

and ρ2 = 0 , and he constructed all biharmonic bases in B .
Consider a biharmonic plane μ := {ζ = x e1 + y e2 : x, y ∈ R} which is a linear span of the elements e1 , e2
of the biharmonic basis (2) over the field of real numbers R . With a domain D of the Cartesian plane xOy
we associate the congruent domain Dζ := {ζ = xe1 + ye2 : (x, y) ∈ D} in the biharmonic plane μ . In what
follows, ζ = x e1 + y e2 and x, y ∈ R .
Inasmuch as divisors of zero don't belong to the biharmonic plane, one can define the derivative Φ′ (ζ) of
function Φ : Dζ −→ B in the same way as in the complex plane:

Φ′ (ζ) := lim
Φ(ζ + h) − Φ(ζ) h−1 .
h→0, h∈μ

We say that a function Φ : Dζ −→ B is monogenic in a domain Dζ if the derivative Φ′ (ζ) exists in every
point ζ ∈ Dζ .
It is established in the paper [1] that a function Φ : Dζ −→ B is monogenic in a domain Dζ if and only if
the following Cauchy–Riemann condition is satisfied
∂Φ(ζ)
∂Φ(ζ)

two-dimensional biharmonic equation

 Therefore, every component Uk : D −→ R , k = 1, 4 , of the expansion
Φ(ζ) = U1 (x, y) e1 + U2 (x, y) ie1 + U3 (x, y) e2 + U4 (x, y) ie2

(6)

satisfies also the equation (5), i.e. Uk is a biharmonic function in the domain D .
It is proved in the paper [3] that a monogenic function Φ : Dζ −→ B has derivatives Φ(n) (ζ) of all orders in
the domain Dζ and, consequently, satisfies the two-dimensional biharmonic equation (5). In the papers [3, 4]
it was also proved such a fact that every biharmomic function U1 (x, y) in a bounded simply connected domain
D is the first component of the expansion (6) of monogenic function Φ : Dζ −→ B determined in an explicit
form.
Basic analytic properties of monogenic functions in a biharmonic plane are similar to properties of holomorphic functions of the complex variable. More exactly, analogues of the Cauchy integral theorem and integral
formula, the Morera theorem, the uniqueness theorem, the Taylor and Laurent expansions are established in
the paper [5].

2

Statement of problem

Consider the following boundary value problem: to find a monogenic function Φ : Dζ −→ B when values of
two components of the expansion (6) are given on the boundary ∂Dζ , i.e. the following boundary conditions
are satisfied:
Uk (x, y) = uk (ζ) , Um (x, y) = um (ζ)
∀ ζ ∈ ∂Dζ , 1 ≤ k < m ≤ 4 ,
where uk and um are given functions.
This problem was first considered by V.F. Kovalev [6] and was called as the biharmonic Schwartz problem
because it is analogous in a certain sense to the classical Schwartz problem on finding an analytic function of
complex variable when values of its real part are given on the boundary of domain.
Let us analyse the main ideas of the paper [6]. V.F. Kovalev proved that all biharmonic Schwartz problem
are reduced to the main three problems:
1) for k = 1 and m = 2 (we shall call it by the (1-2)-problem);
2) for k = 1 and m = 3 (we shall call it by the (1-3)-problem);
3) for k = 1 and m = 4 (we shall call it by the (1-4)-problem).
Some relations between biharmonic Schwartz problems and problems of the theory of elasticity are described
in the paper [6]. In particular, it is shown that the main biharmonic problem (see, for example, [7, p. 202])
on finding a biharmonic function U : D −→ R with given limiting values of its partial derivatives ∂U/∂x and
∂U/∂y on the boundary ∂D can be reduced to the (1-3)-problem.
If certain natural conditions are satisfied, then the (1-4)-problem is solved in [6] in an explicit form. Further,
the (1-2)-problem and the (1-3)-problem are reduced to integro-differential equations with using a conformal
mapping of a domain Dζ onto the half-plane Π+ := {ζ = xe1 + ye2 : y > 0} and the (1-4)-problem as an
auxiliary problem. Note that V.F. Kovalev [6] stated only a sketch of solving biharmonic Schwartz problems,
and he did not investigate conditions of solvability of these problems.
Having an intention to reduce the (1-3)-problem to integral equations, we study boundary properties of
certain integral representations of monogenic functions. Considering the (1-3)-problem for a half-plane and for
a disk under natural assumptions on the functions u1 and u3 , we obtain solutions in explicit forms. Moreover,
the (1-3)-problem is solvable unconditionally for a half-plane but it is solvable for a disk if and only if a certain
condition is satisfied.

4

(1-3)-problem for a half-plane

Let continuous functions u1 : R −→ R and u3 : R −→ R have finite limits of the form (7).
Consider the following (1-3)-problem for the half-plane Π+ : to find a continuous function Φ : Π+ −→ B
which is monogenic in the domain Π+ and has the limit
lim

kζk→∞, ζ∈Π+

Φ(ζ) =: Φ(∞) ∈ B ,

when values of the components U1 and U3 of the expansion (6) are given on the real line R , i.e. the following
boundary conditions are satisfied:
U1 (ξ, 0) = u1 (ξ) ,

U3 (ξ, 0) = u3 (ξ)

∀ξ ∈ R.

It follows from Lemma 1 that the function
Φ(ζ) = SΠ+ [u1 ](ζ) e1 + SΠ+ [u3 ](ζ) e2

(17)

is a solution of (1-3)-problem for the half-plane Π+ if the functions u1 and u3 satisfy the same conditions as
the function u in Lemma 1.

 To describe all solutions of (1-3)-problem for Π+ , first consider the homogeneous (1-3)-problem.
Lemma 2. All solutions Φ : Π+ −→ B of the homogeneous (1-3)-problem for the half-plane Π+ with zero
data u1 = u3 ≡ 0 are expressed in the form
Φ(ζ) = a1 ie1 + a2 ie2 ,

Finally, substituting the obtained functions F , F0 into the equality (19) and taking into account the

In the following theorem we establish the formula of solutions of the (1-3)-problem for the half-plane Π+ .
Theorem 1. Let the functions u1 : R −→ R and u3 : R −→ R have finite limits of the form (7) and
satisfy conditions of the form (8) and (9). Then the general solution of (1-3)-problem for Π+ is expressed in
the form
Φ(ζ) = SΠ+ [u1 ](ζ) e1 + SΠ+ [u3 ](ζ) e2 + a1 ie1 + a2 ie2 ,
(21)
where a1 , a2 are any real constants.
Proof. It is obvious that the formula (21) represents the solution of the (1-3)-problem for Π+ as the sum
of particular solution (17) and the general solution (18) of the homogeneous (1-3)-problem. The theorem is
proved.

6

(1-3)-problem for a disk

Let the functions u1 : ∂Dζ −→ R and u3 : ∂Dζ −→ R satisfy the condition of the form (24).
Consider the following (1-3)-problem for the unit disk Dζ : to find a continuous function Φ : Dζ −→ B
which is monogenic in the disk Dζ when values of the components U1 and U3 of the expansion (6) are given
on the circle ∂Dζ , i.e. the following boundary conditions are satisfied:
U1 (x, y) = u1 (ζ) ,

U3 (x, y) = u3 (ζ)

∀ ζ ∈ ∂Dζ .

(28)

It follows from a biharmonic analogue of the Cauchy integral formula (see Theorem 4 from the paper [5])
that the solution Φ(ζ) of (1-3)-problem for Dζ can be represented as a biharmonic Cauchy integral and,
consequently, it can also be represented in the form

We shall find solutions of (1-3)-problem for Dζ in the class M of functions represented in the form (29),
where the function φ : ∂Dζ −→ B satisfies the condition of the form (24). The solvability of (1-3)-problem for
Dζ in the class M is described in the following theorem.
Theorem 2. Let the functions u1 : ∂Dζ −→ R and u3 : ∂Dζ −→ R satisfy the condition of the form
(24). Then (1-3)-problem for Dζ is solvable in the class M if and only if the following condition is satisfied:

where g1 : ∂Dζ −→ R , g3 : ∂Dζ −→ R are certain functions satisfying the condition of the form (24), and
h1 , h2 , h3 ∈ B .
It follows from a biharmonic analogue of the Cauchy integral theorem (see Theorem 4 from the paper [5])
that for the function (33) the following equalities must be fulfilled:

Consequently, we have a system of six equations with six real unknowns ak,m (with k = 1, 3 and
m = 0, 1, 2 ) and two hypercomplex parameters h1 , h3 :
a1,0 = −C3 − D1 − U1 [h3 ],

It is obvious that this system is solvable if and only if A1 − B3 = B3 − A1 , i.e. A1 = B3 that is equivalent
to the condition (30). If this condition is satisfied, then the general solution of the system (38) contains an
arbitrary real number a1,2 and is of the form:

the formula (40) is reduced to the form (31). The theorem is proved.
Let E := {(x, y) ∈ R2 : x2 + y 2 < 1} be the unit disk in the plane R2 .
Consider the main biharmonic problem (see, for example, [7, p. 202]) on finding a biharmonic function
V : E −→ R with given limiting values of its partial derivatives on the boundary ∂E :
lim

∂V (x, y)
= u1 (x0 , y0 ),
∂x

= u3 (x0 , y0 )

(x,y)→(x0 ,y0 ), (x,y)∈E

(x,y)→(x0 ,y0 ), (x,y)∈E

(41)
∀ (x0 , y0 ) ∈ ∂E.

It is shown in the paper [6] that this problem can be reduced to the (1-3)-problem. Indeed, consider in the
domain Dζ a monogenic function
Φ1 (ζ) := V (x, y) e1 + V2 (x, y) ie1 + V3 (x, y) e2 + V4 (x, y) ie2

 for which U1 [Φ1 (ζ)] = V (x, y) . It follows from the Cauchy–Riemann condition (4) with Φ = Φ1 that
∂V3 (x, y)/∂x = ∂V (x, y)/∂y . Therefore,
Φ′1 (ζ) =

and the main biharmonic problem with the boundary conditions (41) can be reduced to (1-3)-problem on finding
a monogenic function Φ(ζ) := Φ′1 (ζ) in the domain Dζ .
Let us note that in this case the equality (30) is the well known necessary and sufficient condition for the
solvability of the main biharmonic problem with the boundary conditions (41), see, for example, [7, p. 202].
Let us also note that the solvability of the (1-3)-problem is analogous to the solvability of Schwartz-type
boundary value problems for polyanalytic functions and for analytic functions of several complex variables.
In the paper [12] the Schwartz-type boundary value problem for the polyanalytic equation in a half-plane is
solved in an explicit form without any complementary conditions. In the paper [13] Schwartz-type boundary
value problems for analytic functions of several complex variables and for the inhomogeneous Cauchy–Riemann
system in a polydisc are considered, ibid. solvability conditions for appropriate boundary value problems are
obtained.
